Norms

Nov 21, 2021

  • Conditions
  • Matrix Norms Induced by Vector Norms
  • Code

A norm is a function that assigns a real-valued length to each vector. In order to conform to a reasonable notion of length, a norm must satisfy the following three conditions. For all vectors $x$ and $y$ and for all scalars $c$ $\in$ $\mathbb{C}$,

Conditions

  1. $\Vert{x}\Vert \ge 0$ and $\Vert{x}\Vert = 0$ only if $x = 0$

  2. $\Vert{x+y}\Vert â‰¤ \Vert{x}\Vert + \Vert{y}\Vert$

  3. $\Vert{cx}\Vert = c\Vert{x}\Vert$


Matrix Norms Induced by Vector Norms

  • Action of A is determined by unit vectors

  • Matrix norm is stretch

\(\Vert{A}\Vert_1\) = Maximum of 1-norm of column vectors of $A$

\(\Vert{A}\Vert_2\) = Largest singular value

$\Vert{A}\Vert_{\infty}$ = Maximum of 1-norm of column vectors of $A^{T}$
